Synopsis:
A historical drama about a Rajput princess forced to marry a Mughal prince so as bring about lasting peace. She is a spirited woman who resents being used as a pawn in the political game and he is a patient man, who wins her over slowly. There are misunderstandings of course, but ultimately love prevails. The story is also a passionate call for communal harmony.


Comments:
Its difficult to vouch for the historical accuracy of this film. Certainly the stories have been dramatised for maximum impact and seem a little less than believable. But if you don't go by history, it is a film historical romance that you will love. The scale of this film is immense and ashutosh Gowariker can legitimitaely cliam to be the Cecil B De Mille of Indian cinema. In a way, it is a film worthy of emulation if only to bring India's past home to the world.

The sheer craftsmanship is outstanding. The expansive camera work, the use of colour as I have rarely seen in an Indian film, the grand and spectacular music - everything contributes to making this film a grand spectacle. If the characters are a bit stereotyped, it can perhaps be forgiven. Its a romance after all! The spectacle is aided by some very competent acting by Hritwik Roshan and a shade less by Aishwarya Rai Bachhan. Rahman's music has won universal praise and technically, this is one of the better films made in India.

Then there is the passionate message of communal unity and harmony that permeates through the film without ever becoming in your face until the last.

If I must criticise, it will be on the length of the film. Three and a half hours is quite a strain, even for a film as well made as this.

Uploader's Notes:
